verses.text: After these things, God tested Abraham and said to him, 'Abraham.' And he replied, 'Here I am.'
verses.comment: This verse marks a divine test of Abraham's faith, not a temptation to evil (see James 1:13). God's direct call foreshadows the importance of hearing and responding to God's voice throughout Scripture (cf. 1 Samuel 3:10; Isaiah 6:8).

verses.text: He said, 'Take your son, your only son Isaac, whom you love, and go to the land of Moriah. Offer him there as a burnt offering on one of the mountains I will show you.'
verses.comment: 'Your only son whom you love' emphasizes Isaac as the beloved, prefiguring the Father's sacrifice of His beloved Son (John 3:16). The location, Moriah, later becomes the site of the temple (2 Chronicles 3:1), connecting this act of faith with future worship.

verses.text: So Abraham rose early in the morning, saddled his donkey, and took two of his young men with him, and Isaac his son. He split the wood for the burnt offering, set out, and went to the place God had told him.
verses.comment: Abraham's prompt obedience is noteworthy, connecting to other instances of his faithfulness. The presence of two young men adds to the witness, and the detail of preparing the wood reinforces the seriousness of the sacrifice.

verses.text: On the third day, Abraham looked up and saw the place from a distance.
verses.comment: The 'third day' is significant, often associated with deliverance and resurrection (Matthew 16:21; 1 Corinthians 15:4). Abraham's journey points to the patience and endurance required in following God's call.

verses.text: Abraham said to his young men, 'Stay here with the donkey; the boy and I will go over there, worship, and we will come back to you.'
verses.comment: Abraham's statement 'we will come back' hints at his faith in God's power to restore life (Hebrews 11:19), and shows confidence even in the face of possible loss. This suggests a spiritual insight into God's promises.

verses.text: Abraham took the wood for the burnt offering and placed it on his son Isaac. He carried the fire and the knife himself. As the two of them walked together,
verses.comment: Isaac carrying the wood echoes Jesus carrying His cross (John 19:17). The elements of sacrifice show both father and son involved, foreshadowing the unity of will between Father and Son.

verses.text: Isaac spoke to Abraham, his father, and said, 'My father!' And he replied, 'Here I am, my son.' Isaac said, 'The fire and the wood are here, but where is the lamb for the burnt offering?'
verses.comment: Isaac's question draws attention to the missing lamb, a motif fulfilled in Christ as the 'Lamb of God' (John 1:29). This verse allows for both literal and spiritual readings about trust and mystery in salvation.

verses.text: Abraham answered, 'God Himself will provide the lamb for the burnt offering, my son.' So the two of them walked on together.
verses.comment: Abraham's prophetic declaration is fulfilled in Christ, whom God provides as the true sacrificial Lamb. This verse invites deeper reflection on divine providence and the unity of God's plan (Romans 8:32).

verses.text: When they arrived at the place God had told him about, Abraham built the altar, arranged the wood, bound Isaac his son, and laid him on the altar on top of the wood.
verses.comment: Abraham's actions, including binding Isaac, are seen as a type of willing submission. Isaac, though silent here, prefigures the obedience of the Son in the New Testament (see Romans 4:25).

verses.text: Abraham reached out his hand and took the knife to slaughter his son.
verses.comment: This dramatic moment highlights complete obedience. Hebrews 11:17 teaches that Abraham was willing to offer up Isaac, trusting in resurrection or restoration if necessary—a key moment for faith and works.

verses.text: But the angel of the LORD called to him from heaven and said, 'Abraham, Abraham!' And he replied, 'Here I am.'
verses.comment: The repetition of Abraham's name emphasizes urgency and importance, much like Moses' call (Exodus 3:4). The angel's intervention marks divine mercy, aligning with countless scriptural themes of God's provision.

verses.text: He said, 'Do not lay your hand on the boy or do anything to him. Now I know that you fear God, since you have not withheld your son, your only son, from Me.'
verses.comment: Abraham’s obedience demonstrated the depth of his faith. 'Your only son' draws a parallel to God's own self-giving in the New Testament, reemphasizing the motif of generous sacrifice.

verses.text: Abraham looked up and saw a ram caught by its horns in a thicket. He went and took the ram and offered it as a burnt offering instead of his son.
verses.comment: The ram as a substitute points to the principle of sacrificial atonement and prefigures Christ's substitutionary death (cf. John 19:14). The sacrificial system is further established, later fulfilled and perfected.

verses.text: So Abraham called the name of that place 'The LORD Will Provide.' To this day it is said, 'On the mountain of the LORD it will be provided.'
verses.comment: The naming of the site connects worship, sacrifice, and providence. Tradition locates this as the site of the future temple, foreshadowing the center of ongoing worship and God's self-revelation in salvation history.

verses.text: The angel of the LORD called to Abraham a second time from heaven
verses.comment: A second call reinforces the significance of God's message and ongoing guidance. The heavenly origin of the call points to an everlasting relationship and a spiritual authority in divine revelation.

verses.text: and said, 'By Myself I swear, declares the LORD: Because you have done this and have not withheld your son, your only son,
verses.comment: God's self-binding oath highlights the certainty and solemnity of His promises (Hebrews 6:13). Repetition of 'your only son' continues the theme of sacrificial love linked to salvation history.

verses.text: 'I will surely bless you and greatly multiply your descendants like the stars of heaven and like the sand on the seashore. Your descendants will possess the gate of their enemies.'
verses.comment: God’s promise of abundance and victory finds fulfillment not only in physical lineage but spiritually through the united people of God. Authority 'at the gates' carries echoes of Matthew 16:18 in relation to the church’s authority.

verses.text: 'And in your seed all the nations of the earth will be blessed, because you have obeyed My voice.'
verses.comment: Universal blessing through Abraham’s seed is fulfilled in Christ (Galatians 3:8), emphasizing obedience as the channel for God’s promise to reach all people—a theme continued through apostolic succession.

verses.text: Then Abraham returned to his young men, and together they got up and went to Beersheba. Abraham lived at Beersheba.
verses.comment: Abraham’s return represents restoration after sacrifice. Beersheba remains a place of worship and covenant, reinforcing God's continued faithfulness through generations.

verses.text: After these things, Abraham was told, 'Look, Milcah has also borne children to your brother Nahor:
verses.comment: The news of Nahor's children introduces the background for Rebecca, connecting the line of Abraham to future generations of faith and promise.

verses.text: Uz the firstborn, Buz his brother, Kemuel the father of Aram;
verses.comment: Uz and Buz were names also known in ancient genealogies. Kemuel as the father of Aram connects Abraham’s line with near eastern peoples, emphasizing the far-reaching effects of the patriarchal blessings.

verses.text: Kesed, Hazo, Pildash, Jidlaph, and Bethuel.'
verses.comment: This genealogy is significant because Bethuel becomes the father of Rebekah, Isaac's future wife, ensuring the purity and continuity of the promised lineage.

verses.text: Bethuel became the father of Rebekah. Milcah bore these eight children to Nahor, Abraham's brother.
verses.comment: The mention of Rebekah links Abraham’s testing and promise with the coming generations, preparing the way for Isaac’s marriage and ongoing covenant blessings.

verses.text: His concubine, whose name was Reumah, also bore children: Tebah, Gaham, Tahash, and Maacah.
verses.comment: The mention of Nahor's concubine and her children demonstrates the broader scope of Abraham’s extended family, yet attention remains on the line leading to the fulfillment of the promise, distinguished from other genealogies.
